content: Corresponding tests and validators should test moreless the same thing. This is not true for at least "1 floor 4 eggs" and "Validator2". Please review the test cases.

Got rid of my last off-by-one and solved it (my approach summed per remaining eggs directly instead of splitting like eulerscheZahl's, made it harder to spot the missing 0-tries segment on top of the building) (still passed 80%, ugh).

So good to go for me, but I do have to report I didn't need memoizing of any sort. What ought to make this problem intractable by basic recursion is the number of "splits" in the theoretical resolution; if I'm not mistaken it's in the order of 2^T provided T<=E, but that's seldom the case here.

There seems to be a closed form lurking.
I suggest giving the number of eggs in another variable to allow more than 3 eggs. That would make it a bit more interesting.

Thank you for comments.
This can overcomplicate algorithm though. I will think on general solution for X egg problem.

For 3 eggs, when asking how many floors I can cover within time t, I get the sequence 1,3,7,14,25,41,63,..., that is http://oeis.org/A004006
4 eggs: http://oeis.org/A055795
5 eggs: http://oeis.org/A057703
I see explicit forms for a fixed number of eggs. Too tired to search for a from with eggs as parameter now.
I solved this puzzle without knowing formula for a(n). I used recursion and memoization.

Looking for references for a closed form decomposition, I discovered A116670. I was certainly not expecting something as explicit.

So, no known closed form for now. Computing is still a natural recursion, so little hope of cheating (binary search or alike). Problem seems to be mostly O((lgN)^2).

It's not too complicated (I solved it here: https://www.codeeval.com/open_challenges/151/).

My basic idea:
say you try to find a solution within time t. Count the number of floors you can cover as follows:
if you only have one egg, you can cover t floors (time is the limiting point).
if t <= remaining eggs, binary search gives 2^m - 1
for t = 1 you can obviosly cover one floor
otherwise do recursion: floors(t, k) = 1 + floors(t-1, k) + floors(t-1, k-1), where k is the number of remaining eggs.
Increment t, until you can cover enough floors.

Add a lookup table and you can easyly solve the problem for numbers close to 2^31 floors.
Done. You were right, algorithm is not complicated.
